cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Herefordshire 7182 tons, Oct. 11.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, October 1.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: THE NATIONAL MUTUAL LIFE ASSOCIATION OF AUSTRALASIA, LTD. EST. 1869.
div.p: Funds exceed £4,000,000. Annual Income exceeds £700,000.
Special privileges offered to British Naval and Military Officers serving in Egypt or the Soudan.
Example of whole Policy Life.
Age of proposer 30. Sum assured £1,000 with profits payable at death. Annual premium covering war risk and foreign residence £28:6:8
Head Office: Cairo, Khedivial Exchange Court.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

First class passengers steamers. Sailing fortnightly from Suez.

Saloon Fares: from Port Said to Gibraltar £9, Marseilles £9, London and Liverpool £14; add £1 to above fare for passengers from Cairo, Ismailia, or Suez. 5 % reduction to families of three or more adults. 15 % reduction on return tickets within 6 months. Reduced rates on streamers not carrying surgeon and stewardess. 31-12-906
Agents: Cairo, Thos. Cook & Son. Port-Said, Cory Brothers & Co. -- For further particulars apply G. BEYTS & Co., Suez.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.

S.S. Androos July 20 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.

div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 1, 15 and 29 October, 12 and 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 4 October, 3 November.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Oct, 3, 19 Nov., 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 24, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

for Books, Stationery, Newspapers, and "Egyptian Gazette" Picture Post Cards.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.p: Open all the year round.
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Ten minutes by carriage or Palais tram from Sidi Gaber.—Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.
RESTAURANT AND BAR OPEN TO NON-RESIDENTS.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was beautiful, but the night was windy on account of the N. W. breeze, which blew after 9 p.m. This morning opens fine and clear with a light N. W. breeze and a steady barometer.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.

An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1906.

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
div.p: We extract the following from an important article in the September number of the "Deutsche Revue," un "German Foreign Policy," which begins by describing the meeting between the (German Emperor and King Edward the most momentous event of the last month. "This incident," the writer says, "leads direct into the centre of European disturbance. A pacific policy in France could only desire the relations between England and Germany to assume a friendly character. A friend of my friend cannot be my enemy. An Anglo-German understanding, therefore, offers for France the best possible guarantee of peace, for no one in Germany thinks of an-aggressive war against France, which, even in the event of victory, could offer us no advantages. Germany has never yet embarked on an aggressive war against France. The ambitions which the French Press attributes to us, now in Tripoli, now in Siam, and, in fact, all over the world, are imaginary. The question therefore forces itself upon us. Why does French diplomacy show itself so anxiously concerned to prevent a rapprochement between Germany and England? As the reason cannot be the preservation of peace, there remains only to account for it the hope of support in case of war, and of a war which Franco intends to bring about.

What induces French diplomacy to persist in this direction is the assurance that England will hold unswervingly, under every Cabinet, to the entente with France, which is regarded as the personal achievement of the King, and which has brought him great popularity and far-reaching political influence in Great Britain. The present Cabinet contains in its ranks, several very Germanophil Ministers, chief among them the War Minister and the Lord Chancellor. The Prime Minister, Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, has also repeatedly and emphatically declared that he sees no reason for England to live in unfriendliness towards Germany. The Foreign Minister Sir Edward Grey, is held to be an exceptionally cool head ; as in the case of the King, his fellow countrymen place unconditional reliance upon his ability. Sir Edward Grey sees in the entente with France the first and most important object of British policy. He is willing also to allow the cultivation of good relations with Germany in so far as this does not injure the entente. Personally he attaches greater importance to a reconciliation' with Russia, which is not, however, in his opinion, as it is in the opinion of the French Press, to be directed against Germany, for he considers that it does not touch Germany. He is guided by his desire to secure a stable condition on the Indian frontier, and reduce the expense of the Army in India, according to the general wish of the Cabinet At the present moment he is engaged in negotiating at St. Petersburg with regard to Thibet in order to avoid friction in that quarter. When once the negotiations with Russia concerning Central Asia have been settled to the satisfaction of Germany, and should negotiations then proceed with regard to the Nearer East, Sir Edward Grey will certainly be prepared to come to terms with many concerning the latter's interests there. The German Empire will in the meantime not regard Anglo-Russian negotiations respecting Central Asia as affecting Germany, and will welcome their conclusion as a favorable symptom for the general peace.

But, differing in this respect from the views of the British Secretary of State, a considerable portion of the British Press advocates an agreement with Russia, not with a view to the diminution of friction in Asia, but in order to bring about, in the sense of the Delcassé policy, a Rapprochement of the three Powers, and as far as possible of the rest of Europe, against Germany. That section of the Press, therefore, regards with disfavor any closer relations between England and Germany, and is persistently at pains to interpret German policy in the same sense. The kernel of Anglo- German relations therefore lies herein, that Sir Edward Grey shall not identify himself with these French interpretations, but meet Germany with confidence. In this respect the ice appears to have been broken at Friedrichshof. Since the meeting at Friedrichshof, we may be justified in assuming that we are travelling, though slowly and step by step, to a period of rapprochement.

Germany could argue with some force, and let us hope not without success, that a peaceful policy for Great Britain can alone consist in holding out-the hand to Germany, and that peace would thereby be much more effectively secured than by congresses and disarmament proposals. The relations between England and France would not be thereby imperilled, since England has irrevocably declared that the entente with France is a permanent basis of her policy. No doubt could exist on that point in France, even if England were to woo Germany openly and without constraint. As for the possibility of a Franco-German rapprochement—that is to say, of the more friendly relations of France to Germany—false hopes and baseless fears would appear still to stand in its way, and an open relationship of friendliness on the part of England towards Germany might materially help to remove them. The policy of ententes outside of Germany and against Germany is uncertain execution and not without danger ill its consequences. This policy of counterpoises will persist, however, as long as England, out of fear of displeasing Paris, continues to treat with coolness the honorable approaches of Germany. Germany is thereby necessarily compelled to remain on her guard. Towards Germany England has only the choice between either the policy, which might easily become disastrous, of an Anglo-French counterpoise, or that of including Germany within the circle of friendships. These logical conclusions can hardly fail to have carried weight at Friedrichshof and in the British Foreign Office. Substantial results will naturally mature only slowly.
Passing, then, to the question of German naval expansion and the comments made upon in the English Press, the author of the article lays down the necessity for England of facing the situation.

England, he says, must reconcile herself to the thought of seeing the German Fleet occupy, alongside of the British Fleet a position commanding andimposing respect on the sea. . . A year ago the beleif did exist in Germany that our relations with England were in a stage analogous to the relations of Prussia and Austria before 1866, and that in all probability a cordial understanding would have to be preceded by a sharp encounter. The estrangement which rendered such a belief possible, though it may not have justified it, in the past. Both nations may feel confident that it will be possible to arrive at a cordial agreement without any pervious armed conflict.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORS.
div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.
F. Phillips & Co.
LADIES' TAILORS.
(high class work only).
CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.
HMS. Venus
H.M.S. Venus arrived yesterday at 4.50 p.m. from Port Said.
Boa Constrictor for Cairo.
A bos constrictor has been added to Cairo Zoo. The donor is Dr Franz Werner.
"Undesirables."
Three more European "andesirables" from the Abdin quarter of Cairo are to be expelled the country.
The Pilgrimage.
A hundred Turkish pilgrims arrived at Port Said on the 13th inst., and are proceeding to the Hedjaz.
Brindisi Mall.
A mail via Port Said and Brindisi per P. & O. steamer will be made up in Alexandria at 3.10 p.m. on Monday next.
Mosque at Tor.
The Ministry of Finance, the Sanitary Admi nistration, and the Wakfs are now contempla ting the construction of a mosque at Tor.
Bathing Fatality.
A native boy, 13, was drowned yesterday in the Mahmoudieb Canal while bathing. The body was recovered, and sent to the hospital for a post-mortem examination.
Italian Mail.
The Florio-Rabattino S.8. Perseo, which is due at Alexandria to-morrow with the Italian mail, left Messina four hours late; consequently the mail will be distributed somewhat later than usual.
Army Schools.
Egyptian Ivory.

The amount of Egyptian ivory, which has arrived in London for the quarterly sales on October 23rd, is 16 tons 5 cwt. The total amount of ivory from all sources, which has arrived up to date, is 26 tons 16 cwt.
Hellopolis Railway.

The Public Works Ministry has approved of the plans of the Heliopolis Oasis Railways Co. 1e the line between Cairo and the Oasis. There are to be first and second class compartments on the cars as well & haremlik..
Pan-Islamism.

A Brussels journal says that an understanding exists between Great Britain and France for mutual assistance in watching the Mohamedans of North Africa, in view of the Pan- Islamic danger reported by Lord Cromer.
St. Vincent de Paul Soolety.

The members of the St. Catherine's Club at Alexandria are giving a benefit perfor mance at the Club on Saturday, the 22nd inst.. at 9 p.m. on behalf of the poor of the St. Vincent de Paul Society at Alexandria.
The Shoubra Murder.

M. Mille, Chancellor of the French Consulate at Cairo, bad a long interview on Thursday with Goubran Bey Muscat, head of the public safety department, in connexion with this murder. M. Mille is now in Alexandria, to pursue his investigations.
Egypt and the Tourists.

According to some statistics given in the European papers, Egypt's average gains from tourists amount to £2,000,000 per annum. Italy and Switzerland's annual proceeds from tourists are estimated at £15,000,000 and £13,000,000 respectively.

div.head: Inspection in Cyprus.
div.p: Brevet Col. A. W. Roper, R.E., C.R.E. in Egypt, will proceed from Cairo to Alexandria on Tuesday, embarking the same day on a Moss Liner for passage to Cyprus, for the purpose of carrying out inspection, duty at that station. He will return via Port Said on completion of the duty.
The Pyramids Murder.

The murder which took place on Tuesday near the Pyramids was committed by a native, in the employ of the victim, who was an American Wakil of a large Daïra. The assassin, who shot his master six times with a revolver has thus far eluded the vigilance of the police.
Jeddah Pilgrim Hospital.

It has been dec'ded to build a hospital at Jeddah for the use of pilgrims. It is to contain 300 beds. Pending its construction a hospital will be established in a suitable building, and the local authorities have demanded the appointment of physicians and the despatch of medicines with the least possible delay.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: BERLITZ SCHOOLS OF LANGUAGES.
div.p: 325 BRANCHES.
French, German, Italian, Greek, Arabic, etc. Private Lessons, Rosidence Lessons, taught by Native Masters ALEXANDRIA: 12 Rue Rosetta (close to
CAIRO
Zizinia Theatre.) 1 Sharia Kamel./ TRIAL LESSONS FREE

div.head: RUSSIAN ROYAL FAMILY.
div.p: A. YACHTING TRIP.
ST. PETERSBURG, September 14.
The Tsar, Tsaritzs, and their children bave left for several days' yachting excursion in the Gulf of Finland.
(Reyter)
ST. PETERSBURG. September 14.
The Czar and Imperial Family are on a craise in the Gulf of Finland
Havas)

div.head: ALARM IN ODESSA.
div.p: ANTI JEWISH ORGANIZATION.
ODESSA, September 14. An Anti-Jewish organization has issued placards throughout the city urging patriots to exterminate the Jews. The population is much alarmed. (Reuter

div.head: PROVINCE OF MUKDEN.
div.p: WITHDRAWAL OF JAPANESE
PEKING, September 14. The British Chargé d'Affaires has informed Sir E. Grey that the Japanese troops have been withdrawn from the Makden province.
(Feuter)

div.head: GERMAN MANOEUVRES.
div.p: BERLIN, September 14.
The manevres, although nothing novel in the shape tactics took place, were more trying than usual for the troops whose behaviour was magnificent. The Emperor William was well pleased. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN BATTLE FLEET.
div.p: THE NEW COMMAND.
BERLIN, September 14.
Prince Henry of Prussia has been appointed
to the command of the active battle fleet in succession to Admiral De Koester.
(Reuter)

div.head: PLOT AGAINST KAISER.
div.p: BERLIN, September 14.
The report of a plot having been discovered at Breslau against the life of the Emperor is
denied.
(Havas)

div.head: GREAT NAVAL GATHERING.
div.p: MARSEILLES, September 14.
A great naval gathering will take place here to-morrow in honour of the visit of President Fallières. French, British, and the other navies in the Mediterranean will be represented.
(Router)

div.head: THE FRENCH PRESIDENT.
div.p: PARIS, September 14.
M. Fallières has left for Marseilles. (Havas)

div.head: CUBA.
div.p: THE RELIEF OF CIENFUEGOS.
HAVANA, September 14. One hundred armed American bluejackets landed here, ard are camped in front of the President's Palace in anticipation of possible aprisings or attacks on the City.
(Peuter)

HAVANA, September 14. The American ganboat Marietta has landed a detachment at Cienfuegos, which the insurgents are besieging. The fortifications have already been damaged. As the result of a conference between President Palma and the American Chargé d'Affaires the bluejackets who were landed here have returned to their ship, leaving a small Legation guard.
In pursuance of the policy of forcing the intervention of the United States the insurgents are burning American-owned angar mills.
(Reuter)

div.head: TRUST ABSORPTION.
div.p: ANOTHER AMERICAN GRAB

LONDON, September 14. It is reported that the United States Rabber Trust Company bas acquired the stock of a large firm here. This is stated to be the final step towards gaining the control of the world's (Teuter supply of rubber.

div.head: EARTHQUAKES IN SICILY.
div.p: ROME, September 14. Frequent earth quake shocks have been felt in Sicily. The inhabitants of Palermo are camping out in the open.
(Rout)

div.head: THE KNIGHT COMMANDER.
div.p: COMPENSATION REFUSED.
LONDON, September 14.

The Russian Government has flatly refused to pay compensation for the sinking of the S.S. Knight Commander. Great Britain has suggested the reference of the whole matter to the Hague Tribunal. The Russian Government has not yet replied. (Reuter)
The claim demanded for the sinking of the Knight Commander amounts to £100,000. Sir Charles Hardinge banded the claim to the Russian Government on the 15th March, 1905.

div.head: THE ARMY REDUCTIONS.
div.p: KING'S FORMAL APPROVAL.

LONDON, September 14. The King has formally approved of Mr. Haldane's Army reductions, which will be carried out under instractions to be issued from time to time. The rednotion of the 3rd Coldstream Guards will be postponed for the present. (Router)

div.head: SIR F. LUGARD.
div.p: RESIGNATION THROUGH ILL-HEALTH.
LONDON, September 14.
DEATH
COKE FRIEND.-On September 15th, after a short illness, E. Coke Friend, in Cairo.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is expected to arrive at Constantinople on the 25th inst.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: Yesterday the Council of Ministers met at San Stefano and decided to promulgate the following decrees:-
1.-Decree for the convocation of the Ghirgeh Mudirieh on the 20th inst. with a view to examine some schemes in reference to agricaltural roads.
2-Decree authorising the deviation made for the Bahr Shibin at Melig village, Shibin Marksz, in 1905.
3.-The Council also decided to apply at once some new regulations regarding petty officials' salaries.
4.-To open a credit of L.E. 81,908 for the Ministry of Public Works to cover the increase of expenses made in the irrigation work in middle Egypt.
5.-To pension Ali Eff. Sargst, Director of the Industrial School at Menoufieh.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Another fatal case of plague occurred at Sáez Hospital yesterday.

div.head: CAIRO FIRES.
div.p: Two outbreaks of fire occurred yesterday in Cairo, one at half-past three a.m. in a shop in the Rae Emad El Din; the other in a house in Bebekieh square. The shop in the Rue Emad El Din was close to a large wood and coal store, which narrowly escaped, thanks to the ghaffirs and police, who promptly extinguished the flames. The Esbekish fire caught the inmates napping-it being the hour of the siesta--and they made a precipitate exit in what clothes they could bundle on.

div.head: ESCAPE OF PRISONERS.
div.p: Four native prisoners who had been sentenced to various terms by the native Court of Port Said, were being conveyed by the noon train to Tourah, when, near Ras-B-h station, one of them jumped from the carriage and took to flight. Four mounted police were immediately sent in parsait, with what result is not known.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS.
div.p: The total from January 1st to September 6th of this year is 834,424 tons, made up as follows:-Welsh, 443,035 tons; Newcastle, 143,728 tons; Scotch, 89,204 tons; Yorkshire, 122,181 tons; other qualities, 43,278 tons. For the same period last year the total was 710,731 ton".

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Roman Prince, with passengers and general cargo, sailed from Manchester on the 13th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 30th September.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Yang-Teé, which left Alexandria for Marseilles on Friday, the 7th inst. arrived in that port on Wednesday last.

div.head: JORDAN WATER CONCESSION.
div.p: HOLY WATER FOR AMERICA.

The Hon. Clifford B. Nadaud, of Covington, Kentucky, Colonel on the staff of the Governor of thst Commonwealth, arrived at Alexandria to-day from Constantinople by the Khedivial Line steamer "Prince Abbas. He is off to Jerusalem this afternoon in connection with the International River Jordan Water Company. This company was only recently formed in the United States with a capital of five million dollars for the purpose of exporting Jordan water for baptismal and other religious purposes connected with Christian ceremonies. Col. Nadand is the President of the Company, and he has just obtained from the Sultan the sole right of shipping Jordan water out of Palestine. As soon as he arrives in Jerusalem he will proceed to the Jordan to take all the necessary measures for making his concession effective. The head offices will be in New York City and there will also be branches in Jerusa lem, London, and elsewhere. The water will be shipped in casks, sealed by the Tarkish Government and the American Conanl under the anpervision of the Patriarch of Jerusalem. The water will be bottled in the United States bonded warehouses. It will be sold at a reasonable figure and is sure to sell well, as Col. Nadand informs us that the water contains many spiritual virtpes.
The first shipment will leave for America in a month's time.

div.head: ASIA MINOR STEAMSHIP CO., LTD.
div.p: The Asia Minor Steam Ship Company, Limited, was founded a few months ago and its registered office is at 22, Water Street, Liverpool. The company was formed to take over and run the steamers, which recently formed part of the fleet of Bell's Asia Minor Steam Ship Company, Limited, now in voluntary liquidation. Mr. E. G. C. Moss and Mr. H. B. Barker, of the firms of Messrs. R. J. Moss and Co., and Messrs. Barker and Co., both of Alexandria, respectively, will act as local directors. Mr. E. Perkins has been appointed manager of the company. All coma unications relating to the company's business should henceforth be addressed to: the Manager., Asia Minor 8.8. Co., Ltd., P. O. Box, No. 820, Alexandria.
The steamers are now running regalarly between Alexandria and Cyprus and the coast of Syria, with occasional calls at Port Said, and offer special facilities for the quick transport of cargo.

div.head: AFFRAY IN NUBIA.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.) Assouan, Saturday, 11 a.m.

A serious affray is reported from Amberkab in the Markez of El Derr. A number of natives had a regular battle over some personal dispute, and engaged with gans, knives and nabouts. One of the combatants is dying and two others were badly wounded.

div.head: TOMB OF HATSHEPSITU.
div.p: A book describing the tomb of the Egyptian Queen Hatshepsita is shortly to be published. This remarkable tomb was only recently discovered at Biban El-Melak, Thebes, and the publication is to be in every respect worthy of the great importance of the subject. Mr. Theodore M.Davis has written the introduction, and Mr. Edouard Naville has contributed an article on the life and monuments of the queen. A description of the discovery and excavations is given by Mr. Howard Carter.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: The Club's new floating bath is ready for use, and a steam launch will leave the Marina at 3.15 p.m. to-day for Ras-el-Tin. Members and friends are requested to meet in fall force, especially those competing in the Sports, for the purpose of having their times taken. For the convenience of those unable to attend on the above date arrangements have been made for boats to leave the Marina as follows:-
Sanday the 16th September
Saturday the 22nd
Sunday the 23rd
Saturday the 29th
Sunday the 30th
at 8.15 p.m. at 11 a.m.
at 8.15 p.m.
at 11 a.m.
Competitors are reminded that slips must be worn underneath costume.

Owing to the heavy outlay the Club has been subjected to in regard to the new bath. members would greatly assist by endeavouring to dispose of as many tickets as possible for the sports to their friends: these can be had on sale or return at P.T. 25 each.
Entry forms for the Gala should be sent in
duly filled up by return to: H. 8. Martin, Hon. Secretary, Treasurer and Handicapper, Alexandria Swimming Clob, P.O. Box 171, Ba Ville.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: There is a variety entertainment this evening
at the New Theatre. The Bracale Orchestra will give a concert tomorrow at 5.30 p.m., when also there will be a variety show in the Theatre and cinema-
tograph.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary Hmitafree discussion.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SALT AND SODA COMPANY, LIMITED.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, Shareholders in the above Company had for some time the satisfaction to receive few shillings per share yearly for dividend and to note from returns published in newspapers the progress of the sales of salt. But since the company deals without monopoly, the proprietors are completely deprived of any comfort whatever.

Many of the shareholders, I believe, will be glad if they are not left in the dark any longer. They must, however, be patient for say another fortnight as all their principal representatives are at present enjoying the last days of their leave of absence in Europe.
Yours faithfully,
SHAREHOLDER
Alexandris, September 14.

div.head: RESPECTING ANTHEMS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE". Sir,-It is unfortunate that "A Twenty Years' Resident in Egypt" upon his return from the villages should have seen fit to continue his insinuati gainst the breeding and tact of his felt untrymen in this country. Let me assure him that his previous letter has caused quite sufficient resentment amongst his fellow-countrymen without his further adding to it. As the criticizer of his remarks, I feel bound to write once more and for the last time on this absurd subject to refate his last letter. If he would be kind enough to read my letter more carefully he would discover that I have been careful to emphasize the fact that it is not the habit of other nations to respect anthems.

That he should find in my letter any sug gestion that the conduct of Englishmen should be guided by that of natives shows him to be possessed of great ingenuity. I merely represented to him the other and commoner side of the picture. In the incident at the Continental Hotel was indeed shewn an attempt on the part of Englishmen to give natives-let them be the skimmed milk of their society if you will!-a lesson in manners with any poor results.

In conclusion, I would merely very that "A Twenty Years' Resident in Egypt" need no longer flatter himself that his words of wondrous wisdom resulted in the springing of every Englishman to his feet on that night!
His unfortunate letter appeared in Cairo the night af er this episode and could have hardly caused this unanimous act of courtesy on the part of every Englishman present for the first time.
I am, etc.,
A HATER OF CALUMNY.
Caire, 13th September.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,-Speaking from memory only, and there fore under correction, it was about 18 years ago when Mr. MacDonald, the then Director of the Egyptian Army Bands, tried to ascertain (a) the origin of the so-called Khedivial Hymn; (b) a copy of the original score and (c) a copy of the words to accompany the music, as no one seemed to know whether it had to be played as a solemn chant or a hybrid polka; the latter rendering seemed to be the favourite as it allowed individual instrumentalists a wide field for variations and embellishments, some of which still obtain. I believe that his researobes resulted in the unearthing of a "fantasia" dedicated to H.B. Ismail Pasha, written by an Italian Music Master and lithographed in Alexandria, one number of which fantasia was the jingle under discussion. As to any words to accompany the music and which might serve as a guide to the interpretation of it, the only ones discovered were those which Mr. Atkins fitted to part of the tune as a mnemonic, in precisely the same manner as he fits his own librettcs to the numerous bugle calls and salutes which are the bane of his existence, and as those who have been privileged to hear them well know, they are intended for private consumption only and may not be instanced here.

I believe I am correct in saying that there is no such thing as "sacred music" appertaining to the Mohammedan religion, therefore Khedivial Hymn or Anthem must be misnomers. The most likely thing is that the jingle was adopted as a "General Salate" years ago, and tacked on to all programmes in the same way as Regimental marches were and still are. To stand uncovered when this "general salute" is played is not exhibiting respect but ignorance. But as I have already sid, I write under correction. Perhaps one of your contributors may be able to enlighten us on the origin of the ro-called Khedivial Hymn.
MUSICA.
Cairo, 14th September.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is probable that Chitty Bey will be transferred to Cairo shortly to occupy a very import ant post.
The rumour that the Director General of the Castoma Administration is to be entrusted with the reorganisation of the Wakfa Administration is not confirmed.
Lord Edward Cecil left for Cairo this morn ing, and returns to-morrow night.
We hear from the Lebanon that Muzaffer Pasha, the Governor of that province, who had been incapacitated for some weeks owing to his serious illness, has now resumed his official duties.
Mr. Branyate, who was here since Thursday, attended yesterday's Council of Ministers and submitted various questions. He left in the evening for Cairo.
Dr. Grabam Bey, of the Pablic Health Department, is leaving to-day for Barope. He will be back on the 10th November.
Sir H. Pinching, Director of the Public Health Department, is expected to arrive in Cairo at the end of this month on his return from Barope.
Mr. Webb left Alexandria yesterday for Cairo.
Mr. Alexander MoBarnet, late Lecturer at the Khedivial Law School, Cairo, is to be appointed Judge of the Native Court of Keneh; the appointment to date from October 1st..
Col. J. Magill, R.A.M.C., P.M.O. in Egypt, accompanied by Captain R.C.Wilson, R.A.M.C., came from Cairo to Alexandria to-day on temporary duty. They are returning this evening.

div.head: NILE VALLEY OPERATIONS.
div.p: Messrs. Lake and Carrie, the company's engineers, report as follows: The total footage for the month ended July 31 last amountod to 189, being an increase of 75 ft. over that for Jane, which was 114. The Main Shaft No. 5 was sunk 38 ft., to a total depth 314 ft. 6 in. and No. 1 Shaft 19 ft. 6 in., to a total depth of 815 ft. Fair progress has been made in the 3rd, or C. level, which is being driven from four faces. The total distance advanced here is 40 ft. 6 in., made up as below:-
Average Average
width
value.
ft. in.
in.
dwt.
Drive north of winze B.N. 1
Drive south of winze B.N. 1 North drive of winze B.8. 1 advanced. 7 0
Drive south of winze B.S. 1 advanced 11 6 4112
The average width and values over the entire distance driven on the 3rd level, namely 181 ft.
6 in., work out as follow:-
Length Average Average
width value.
ft. in.
in.
dwt.
Drive north of main shaft cross-cut 87 6 175 Drive south of main shaft cross-cut 44 0

The cross-cut mentioned above was commenced from the 3rd level to connect with the main shaft, and at the end of the month had advanced 16 ft. Work is proceeding in several other faces in the upper levels; but there is little or no change to report.

Plant.-Mr. C. 8. Bell (oar chief engineer) has lately visited the mine, in connection with the provision of additional motive power for milling. As a result of his investigations, it has been decided to instal two large oil engines of the slow-speed horizontal type. These are being supplied by Messrs. Hornsby, and will be ready for delivery shortly. It is expected that these new units will come into operation at the mines about the end of December. In addition to the above, we are pleased to state that Mr. Bell was able to effect such uniformity in the handling and operation of the hoisting, pamping, and condensing plant as to result in an immediate fuel economy of over 25 per cent., and it is expected that this saving will be farther increased to about 40 per cent. in the near future. Should this latter figure be attained, it will represent a fuel economy of nearly £2,000 per annum. A supply of coal sufficient for at least nine months has been purchased on very favourable terms, and is now in course of delivery.

En outre, aux termes da concordat, les 102,405 obligations ordinaires 4 % de Frs 500 restant en circulation doivent être échangées contre de nouvelles obligations ordinaires de Prs. 400, remboursables & Pro. 500 en 60 ans,
revena variable, maximam 5%, aves é. chéance da lør Jaillet 1909 pour le ler coupon.

Aa momeat de l'échange des obligations, les porteurs pourront demander l'échange avec l'estampille donnant droit à un coupon de 8 francs pendant 3 ans, payable par semestre, pour le premier paiement qui doit avoir lieu le ler Juillet 1906, et ce aux charges et conditions de l'art. 3 da concordat.

L'optio, pour l'estampille des titres prend fio le 20 Septembre courant. Pour l'échange des titres (actions et obligations), les portears en Egypte peavent s'adresser: au Caire, au siège de la Société, à la National Bank et à l'Anglo Bgyptian Bank; à Alexandrie : à l'A. gence du Crédit Lyonnais.
